title: Rethinking thinking - Trevor Maber

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model that describes how our subconscious mind processes experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ladder of Inference

options.label: B
options.text: The Model of Perception

options.label: C
options.text: The Theory of Assumptions

options.label: D
options.text: The Framework of Beliefs

multiple-choice.question: According to the Ladder of Inference, what happens on the first rung of the ladder?

options.label: A
options.text: We assign meaning to the information we have filtered through.

options.label: B
options.text: We develop assumptions based on the meaning we created on the previous rung.

options.label: C
options.text: We filter in specific information and details from our experience.

options.label: D
options.text: We take action based on our adjusted beliefs.

multiple-choice.question: What happens on the fourth rung of the Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: We develop conclusions based on our assumptions.

options.label: B
options.text: We adjust our beliefs about the world around us.

options.label: C
options.text: We develop assumptions based on the meaning we created on the previous rung.

options.label: D
options.text: We take action based on our adjusted beliefs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of being able to short-circuit our ladders ourselves?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to react more quickly to our experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables us to take more control of our thoughts and emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives us the ability to change our beliefs and assumptions more easily.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps us to become more aware of our thoughts and emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the function that allows us to take control of our thoughts and emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ladder of Inference

options.label: B
options.text: The Model of Perception

options.label: C
options.text: The Theory of Assumptions

options.label: D
options.text: Free Will

title: How does math guide our ships at sea? - George Christoph

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem with dead reckoning, a process used by sailors to navigate the open ocean 400 years ago?

options.label: B
options.text: It required too many people.

options.label: C
options.text: Being just half a degree off could result in sailing right past the island that lay several miles just over the horizon.

options.label: D
options.text: It was too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: A sextant.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A telescope.

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What was the main challenge with using John Harrison's clock at sea?

options.label: C
options.text: It was handmade, making it very expensive.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: Helium

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our breathing when we experience physical or emotional stress?

options.label: A
options.text: Our breathing becomes slower and shallower.

options.label: B
options.text: Our breathing becomes faster and more labored.

options.label: C
options.text: Our breathing becomes more regular and consistent.

options.label: D
options.text: Our breathing becomes completely stopped.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles in our breathing system?

options.label: A
options.text: To move air from the lungs to the alveoli.

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate air exchange between the alveoli and the blood.

options.label: C
options.text: To pump air into the lungs and out of the body.

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature by allowing it to cool down naturally.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our body when we breathe under stress over long periods of time?

options.label: A
options.text: Our body becomes more efficient at delivering oxygen to our cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Our body becomes less efficient at delivering oxygen to our cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Our body remains the same in terms of oxygen delivery.

options.label: D
options.text: Our body starts to produce more oxygen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of paying attention to our breathing and changing it to improve the quality and quantity of oxygen that enters our body?

options.label: B
options.text: It lowers stress, increases energy, and strengthens our immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on our stress levels, energy, or immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases stress and decreases energy, while weakening our immune system.

title: Why do competitors open their stores next to one another? - Jac de Haan

multiple-choice.question: According to Hotelling's Model of Spatial Competition, where would you place your ice cream cart to sell the most product if you were the only seller on a one-mile long beach?

options.label: A
options.text: At the northern end of the beach

options.label: B
options.text: At the southern end of the beach

options.label: C
options.text: In the middle of the beach

options.label: D
options.text: At the edge of the beach

multiple-choice.question: In Hotelling's Model, what happens when two ice cream vendors, you and your cousin Teddy, agree to split the beach in half to ensure customers don't have to walk too far?

options.label: A
options.text: You both set up your carts at the northern end of the beach

options.label: B
options.text: You both set up your carts at the southern end of the beach

options.label: C
options.text: You set up your cart a quarter mile south of the beach center, and Teddy sets up his cart a quarter mile north of the center

options.label: D
options.text: You set up your cart at the middle of the beach, and Teddy sets up his cart at the edge of the beach

multiple-choice.question: What is the socially optimal solution in Hotelling's Model, according to game theorists?

options.label: A
options.text: The point where one vendor serves 75% of the customers and the other vendor serves 25% of the customers

options.label: B
options.text: The point where neither vendor can improve their position by deviating from their current strategy

options.label: C
options.text: The point where both vendors serve 50% of the customers

options.label: D
options.text: The point where one vendor serves all the customers and the other vendor serves none

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two vendors, you and your cousin Teddy, reach a Nash Equilibrium in Hotelling's Model?

options.label: A
options.text: You both set up your carts at the northern end of the beach

options.label: B
options.text: You both set up your carts at the southern end of the beach

options.label: C
options.text: You both set up your carts at the middle of the beach, back to back, each serving 50% of the customers

options.label: D
options.text: You both set up your carts at the edge of the beach

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows them to serve more customers

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows them to differentiate their product line

options.label: C
options.text: Because it minimizes the maximum number of steps any visitor must take to reach a service

options.label: D
options.text: Because it allows them to compete with marketing strategies and price cuts

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: In scientific texts.

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: Metaphors are a way to make the strange familiar.

options.label: D
options.text: Plane polarization

title: Newton’s 3 Laws, with a bicycle - Joshua Manley

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's First Law, what happens to an object that is at rest?

options.label: A
options.text: It stays at rest and never moves.

options.label: B
options.text: It stays at rest, but can move at any time.

options.label: C
options.text: It tends to stay at rest, but can be moved by a force.

options.label: D
options.text: It tends to stay at rest, but can spontaneously speed up or slow down.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between force and acceleration, according to Newton's Second Law?

options.label: A
options.text: Force is the product of mass times velocity.

options.label: B
options.text: Force is the product of mass times acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: Force is the product of velocity times time.

options.label: D
options.text: Force is the product of mass times distance.

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Third Law, what happens when you drop a bouncy ball?

options.label: A
options.text: The ball hits the floor and stays there.

options.label: B
options.text: The ball hits the floor and bounces back up to you.

options.label: C
options.text: The ball hits the floor and causes a force on the floor, but the floor does not react.

options.label: D
options.text: The ball hits the floor and causes a force on the floor, but the force is not equal and opposite.

multiple-choice.question: Why does your bicycle go forward when you pedal it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the force of the pedals pushing down on the ground propels you forward.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the ground pushes forward on the tires with the same force as the tires push backwards.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Earth is moving and pulls your bicycle along with it.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bicycle wheels spin clockwise and create a force that propels you forward.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of applying a greater force to a bicycle with a greater mass?

options.label: A
options.text: The bicycle accelerates more quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: The bicycle accelerates at the same rate.

options.label: C
options.text: The bicycle accelerates more slowly.

options.label: D
options.text: The bicycle does not accelerate at all.

title: Magical metals, how shape memory alloys work - Ainissa Ramirez

multiple-choice.question: What is the width of an atom compared to a human hair?

options.label: A
options.text: The width of an atom is similar to the width of a human hair.

options.label: B
options.text: The width of an atom is 100 times the width of a human hair.

options.label: C
options.text: The width of an atom is 1/100,000 the width of a human hair.

options.label: D
options.text: The width of an atom is 1/10,000 the width of a human hair.

multiple-choice.question: What is a phase change in the context of atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: A phase change is when atoms move from one solid phase to another.

options.label: B
options.text: A phase change is when atoms change their seating arrangement.

options.label: C
options.text: A phase change is when atoms move from one liquid phase to another.

options.label: D
options.text: A phase change is when atoms change their temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What is a shape memory alloy?

options.label: A
options.text: A shape memory alloy is a metal that remembers its original shape.

options.label: B
options.text: A shape memory alloy is a metal that remembers different shapes.

options.label: C
options.text: A shape memory alloy is a metal that changes shape when heated.

options.label: D
options.text: A shape memory alloy is a metal that changes shape when cooled.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of shape memory alloys in the Mars rover?

options.label: A
options.text: To move panels on the Mars rover so that it can study the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: To heat up the Mars rover so that it can move faster.

options.label: C
options.text: To cool down the Mars rover so that it can move slower.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide power to the Mars rover.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the uses of shape memory alloys in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: To move joints in the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To open up clogged arteries as stents.

options.label: C
options.text: To move teeth in the mouth.

options.label: D
options.text: To move hair in the head.

title: How to think about gravity - Jon Bergmann

multiple-choice.question: What is the equation for the law of gravity?

options.label: A
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R

options.label: B
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R^2

options.label: C
options.text: F = G x M1 / R^2

options.label: D
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R^3

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when two objects with mass are placed far out in space?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not attracted to each other

options.label: B
options.text: They are repelled by each other

options.label: C
options.text: They are attracted to each other

options.label: D
options.text: They remain stationary

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts weigh less on the moon than on the earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the moon is more massive than the earth

options.label: B
options.text: Because the moon is less massive than the earth

options.label: C
options.text: Because the moon is the same mass as the earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the universal gravitational constant (G) in the equation for the law of gravity?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is still a mystery to scientists?

options.label: B
options.text: The cause of gravity

options.label: C
options.text: The cause of friction

options.label: D

title: Why the shape of your screen matters - Brian Gervase

multiple-choice.question: What is the original standard television aspect ratio?

options.label: A
options.text: 16 to 9

options.label: B
options.text: 4 to 3

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to fit movie screens onto standard TV screens?

options.label: A
options.text: Because movie screens are too small.

options.label: B
options.text: Because movie screens are too large.

options.label: C
options.text: Because movie screens have a different aspect ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: Because movie screens are not rectangular.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "pan and scan" technique used for in movie editing?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow the full height of the TV screen to be used, but pick and choose what section of the original movie should be shown on the screen.

options.label: B
options.text: To cut a chunk of the original movie like a cookie cutter and just see that frame of the movie.

options.label: C
options.text: To squeeze and stretch everything onto the screen to make it all fill up.

options.label: D
options.text: To shrink the movie screen proportionally to fit the width of the screen.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of a movie can actually fit on a standard 4 to 3 TV screen at any one time?
What is the aspect ratio of some widescreen TVs that emerged in the early 21st century?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 to 3

options.label: B
options.text: 16 to 9

title: A clever way to estimate enormous numbers - Michael Mitchell

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using scientific notation in expressing large numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the numbers easier to memorize.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the numbers more difficult to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: To express the numbers in a more manageable format.

options.label: D
options.text: To convert the numbers into different units.

options.label: A
options.text: A problem that requires the use of advanced mathematical formulas.

options.label: B
options.text: A problem that involves the use of scientific notation.

options.label: C
options.text: A problem that requires rapid order-of-magnitude estimations.

options.label: D
options.text: A problem that involves the use of complex calculations.

multiple-choice.question: In a Fermi problem, what is assumed to balance out overestimates and underestimates?

options.label: A
options.text: The exact values of the estimates.

options.label: B
options.text: The order of magnitude of the estimates.

options.label: C
options.text: The uncertainty of the estimates.

options.label: D
options.text: The overestimates and underestimates themselves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of piano tuners in Chicago, based on the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 to the 4th

options.label: B
options.text: 10 to the 6th

options.label: C
options.text: 10 to the 8th

options.label: D
options.text: 10 to the 10th

multiple-choice.question: What is the power of 10 used for in Fermi problems?

options.label: A
options.text: To make quick estimations of exact values.

options.label: B
options.text: To make rapid order-of-magnitude estimations.

options.label: C
options.text: To convert the numbers into different units.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the numbers easier to memorize.

options.label: C

title: How taking a bath led to Archimedes’ Principle - Mark Salata

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem that Archimedes was asked to solve by the king of Sicily?

options.label: A
options.text: He had to find a way to make a new crown.

options.label: B
options.text: He had to investigate if a goldsmith had cheated the king by slipping some silver into a gold crown.

options.label: C
options.text: He had to calculate the exact amount of gold needed to make a crown.

options.label: D
options.text: He had to measure the volume of a gold crown.

multiple-choice.question: What discovery did Archimedes make while taking his bath that helped him solve the king's problem?

options.label: A
options.text: He discovered that water is less dense than gold.

options.label: B
options.text: He discovered that the volume of an object is equal to its mass.

options.label: C
options.text: He discovered that the amount of water displaced in a bathtub is equal to the volume of the object immersed in it.

options.label: D
options.text: He discovered that the density of an object is equal to its volume divided by its mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the method Archimedes used to measure the volume of the crown?

options.label: A
options.text: Archimedes' principle

options.label: B
options.text: Archimedes' method

options.label: C
options.text: The displacement method

options.label: D
options.text: The volume calculation method

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Archimedes' test on the crown?

options.label: A
options.text: The crown was found to be made of pure gold.

options.label: B
options.text: The crown was found to be less dense than pure gold.

options.label: C
options.text: The crown was found to be the same density as pure gold.

options.label: D
options.text: The test was inconclusive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the field of study that Archimedes was a part of?

options.label: A
options.text: Mathematics

options.label: B
options.text: Physics

options.label: C
options.text: Engineering

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: B: He had to investigate if a goldsmith had cheated the king by slipping some silver into a gold crown.

D: All of the above
